key_insight: Decompose full browser interaction into nested layers of decision-making and observation compression so agents can perform rich, fine‑grained web actions without being overwhelmed by verbose page content.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between lightweight API/URL retrieval and full browser control by addressing the complexity and verbosity that break ReAct-style function-calling agents during deep web information-seeking.
method: Nested/hierarchical agent design: a high-level planner issues goals, mid-level modules choose browsing subgoals, and low-level controllers emit DOM-level actions.
Intermediate compression and abstraction: summarize or extract salient page content into compact observations to reduce bandwidth and decision noise for the policy.

Tool and training wrappers: present browser capabilities as structured, learnable primitives (click, scroll, extract, follow link) and train via imitation/agentic learning to coordinate nested modules.
impact: Enables agents to leverage the full richness of real browsing for deeper, multi-step information tasks while remaining robust and efficient; practical for building stronger web-capable assistants and search agents.
visual_elements: Layered architecture diagram showing high-level planner → mid-level subgoal modules → low-level browser controller (DOM actions)
Flowchart of an information-seeking episode: query → nested decisions → browser actions → compressed observations → updated plan
Before/after bar chart or infographic: reduced observation size and fewer failed/irrelevant actions when using nested learning vs. flat ReAct
Icons: web browser, magnifying glass, hierarchical nodes, and a summarized document symbol to represent compression
paper_title: Nested Browser-Use Learning for Agentic Information Seeking
paper_authors: Baixuan Li, Jialong Wu, Wenbiao Yin, Kuan Li, Zhongwang Zhang
